section: This Agreement be deemed effective as of the Effective Date, Agreement and shall terminate on December 31, 2020, unless terminated earlier in accordance with Section 3.2.
explanation: The sentence is not grammatically correct and does not make sense. It seems to be missing a word or has an extra word. The phrase 'Agreement be deemed effective' is not proper English.

section: Each of the Recipient and the Provider may, in their sole discretion, terminate this Agreement in whole or in part, at any time without cause. However, termination by either party is subject to a termination fee of [ * * * ], and liability may arise based on a review of outstanding commitments. To do so, providing at least 90 (ninety) days' prior written notice to the other party (such date, the "Services Termination Date").
explanation: This section contains an inconsistency in text. It states that either party can terminate the agreement at any time without cause, but then it imposes a termination fee and a 90-day prior written notice requirement. These conditions contradict the 'at any time without cause' clause, creating ambiguity around the actual termination process.

section: Notices sent via mail are deemed received upon dispatch, regardless of actual delivery or return receipt.
explanation: This creates an ambiguity in legal terms. Under common legal standards, receipt of notice is typically required for it to be effective. Stating that a notice is deemed received upon dispatch, regardless of actual delivery or return receipt, could lead to disputes and potential unenforceability under standard legal practices. This contradicts standard legal practice that requires proof of receipt.
